epic.title: Enhance Telemetry across Meltano, SDK, and Hub

_decoded_content.title: Bug - Missing Anonymous Events
_decoded_content.description:
As related to the discussion in https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3296#note_861908315 (internal) about potentially tracking events inside the Airflow dag generator, I noticed that the `schedule list --format=json` commands https://gitlab.com/meltano/files-airflow/-/blob/master/bundle/orchestrate/dags/meltano.py#L48 and `meltano schedule run` https://gitlab.com/meltano/files-airflow/-/blob/master/bundle/orchestrate/dags/meltano.py#L99 that the Airflow dag generator runs are not being tracked at all. This would give us a better way to infer Airflow usage as that command is run every time the DAG file is parsed by Airflow ([min_file_process_interval](https://airflow.apache.org/docs/apache-airflow/stable/configurations-ref.html#min-file-process-interval) defaults to every 30 seconds).

This led me to check out the other CLI commands in https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/tree/master/src/meltano/cli that might be missing tracking and I dont think these are tracked either:

- Schedule (list - already mentioned and run?)
- Config
- Environment
- Model
- Remove
- Schema
- Upgrade
- User Add
- UI Store?

There might be good reason for not tracking certain commands but I think we should do a full audit to make sure we have full coverage.

epic.title: Enhance Telemetry across Meltano, SDK, and Hub

_decoded_content.title: Challenges with tracking Airflow usage
_decoded_content.description:
I _think_ we have a problem with tracking Airflow usage. Opening this issue to confirm if we do/don't have the necessary visibility.

If the visibility is lacking, this issue can be used to explore options to improve the metric or introduce new tracking methods.

## Problem with using `meltano run ... airflow ...` or `meltano invoke airflow ...`

The challenge with these two approaches is that they miss invocations that are invoked from already-scheduled Airflow jobs.

@tayloramurphy and @pnadolny13 - Is this something you've already mitigated for? Or, asked another way, do we get 'airflow' usage metric ticked when Meltano tasks are invoked _from_ airflow? After scheduling is done, it seems you could go several months without invoking or calling airflow directly.

epic.title: Enhance Telemetry across Meltano, SDK, and Hub

_decoded_content.title: Consider using a `https` scheme in default Snowplow collector endpoint
_decoded_content.description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.

If you are submitting an issue with a tap, please include:

- account details
- target details
- entities selected  with meltano select (if you have selected any entities), as the bug may be related to a specific entity
- the full elt command you are running
- full output of the meltano elt command. Logs can get pretty long, so you can add the full log as a snippet in the Meltano project and add a link in the issue.
--->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
_What is happening now?_

Default Snowplow event emitter is created for an `http` endpoint when it should be `https`.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
_What should be happening?_

The default value of `snowplow.collector_endpoints` should contain an `https` endpoint.

Note that `http` may be OK if a redirect is added on the SnowcatCloud side.

### Steps to reproduce
_How one can reproduce the issue?_

NA

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
_Please use code blocks (\`\`\`) to format console output_

NA

### Possible fixes
_If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem or suggest a fix_

Change the value in `src/meltano/core/bundle/settings.yml`

### Further regression test
_Ensure we automatically catch similar issues in the future_

- [ ] Write additional adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

epic.title: Enhance Telemetry across Meltano, SDK, and Hub

_decoded_content.title: Limit the Snowplow tracker logs
_decoded_content.description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.

If you are submitting an issue with a tap, please include:

- account details
- target details
- entities selected  with meltano select (if you have selected any entities), as the bug may be related to a specific entity
- the full elt command you are running
- full output of the meltano elt command. Logs can get pretty long, so you can add the full log as a snippet in the Meltano project and add a link in the issue.
--->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
_What is happening now?_

The snowplow tracker library is printing logs on every CLI invocation that is tracked. This is a bit distracting and not something we want users to see all the time.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
_What should be happening?_

Commands should not display tracking logs by default.

### Steps to reproduce
_How one can reproduce the issue?_

1. Run any CLI command that is currently tracked in GA
1. Don't use any custom `logging.yaml` so the the default logging config is used
1. Notice the log lines at the end re Snowplow tracking coming from the libray

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
_Please use code blocks (\`\`\`) to format console output_

![image](/uploads/30ff0d66caaccec6287ebcaf3828fdee/image.png)

### Possible fixes
_If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem or suggest a fix_

Set the level of the `snowplow_tracker.emitters` logger in the default config to `ERROR`.

With that change, these lines can probably be removed:

- https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/cli-init-experience/src/meltano/cli/initialize.py#L36 (see https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/merge_requests/2562)
- https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/02a512b62ac5a8c63a0aff25763cde915fdeec12/tests/meltano/core/test_tracking.py#L44-45

### Further regression test
_Ensure we automatically catch similar issues in the future_

- [ ] Write additional adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

_decoded_content.title: Increase adoption of telemetry
_decoded_content.description:
One of the challenges with our current collection of usage stats is we make it very easy to opt-out. 

We should consider ways of nudging users to share more data by explaining the benefits and making it easier to say yes.

_decoded_content.title: Setup subdomain for meltano.com
_decoded_content.description:
We're implementing snowplow event tracking and we need to setup a subdomain at sp.meltano.com with the following NS record (per the instructions I got in email):

Step 1. Setup DNS (sp.meltano.com)
Add a NS record under meltano to the subdomain you will want to collect the data. If you opt for a different subdomain name please let us know.

DNS Setup
|Type|	Name|	Value|	TTL|
|:-:|:-:|:-:|:-:|
|NS|	sp|	ns-2013.awsdns-59.co.uk	| 10 minutes |
|NS|	sp|	ns-1020.awsdns-63.net	| 10 minutes |
|NS|	sp|	ns-355.awsdns-44.com	| 10 minutes |
|NS|	sp|	ns-1191.awsdns-20.org	| 10 minutes |

@afolson is this something you can do in the next day or two?

cc @aaronsteers 

<!-- Labels to add for triaging -->

_decoded_content.title: Hashed plugin ID(s) in snowplow events
_decoded_content.description:
From https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3141#note_804763357>

> Eventually, I'd like to see at least a one-way hash of the plugins' variant name and pip_url if available - since collisions on plugin name are basically the rule rather than exception.
> 
> Some pseudocode...
> 
> ```python
>     def _hashed_plugin_id(plugin_def: Plugin) -> :
>         """Return a unique obfuscated/anonymized string ID representing this plugin.
>         String is delimited for later parsing into component parts, in case one part is known
>         to Meltano and and other part is unknown.
>         """
>         hash_fn = md5  # or sha256, or similar.
> 
>         result = hash_fn(Plugin.name)
>         if Plugin.variant_name:
>             result = f"{result}::{hash_fn(Plugin.variant_name)}"
> 
>         if Plugin.pip_url:
>             result = f"{result}@@{hash_fn(Plugin.pip_url)}"
>     
>         return result
> 
>     ...
>     event = self.track_event(
>             category="meltano run",
>             action=f"meltano run [the lists of args...]",
>             debug=debug,
>             plugins_used=[_hashed_plugin_id(plugin_def) for plugin_def in referenced_plugins]
>        )
> ```
>

epic.title: Enhance Telemetry across Meltano, SDK, and Hub

_decoded_content.title: Snowplow - Custom Event Structure
_decoded_content.description:
This relates to https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3019#note_806164352.

**ORIGINAL**

In Snowplow [custom structured event](https://docs.snowplowanalytics.com/docs/collecting-data/collecting-from-own-applications/python-tracker/tracking-specific-events/#struct-event) map most closely to our current Google Analytics CLI events but I think we might prefer [self describing](https://docs.snowplowanalytics.com/docs/understanding-tracking-design/out-of-the-box-vs-custom-events-and-entities/#custom-events) events where we define a schema and can send whatever we want, this just requires us to come up with a schema to define how those events look.

If we define events ourselves, I see 2 different ways:
1. A single generic CLI event type.
1. A custom event schema per CLI command category (invoke/elt/run/test/ui/add/etc.) we want to track.

I think we'd want to go with option 2 to allow for more/less detail depending on the command and lets us be more strict.

I'm also interested in how we want to balance having Meltano parse out properties of an event prior to sending vs us doing the parsing in the warehouse. For example right now we need to parse CLI events in dbt which is very brittle and theres lots of room for mislabeling due features not explicitly called in a command (i.e. environments set using an environment variable vs `--environment=x`).

The pro of having Meltano do it is that it has all the context of what the CLI command was doing, especially given the fact that many of the features can be called in implicit way. The con is that we have less flexibility to change logic once data arrives in the warehouse. We should try to land at a place where Meltano can send us component parts that we can logically parse in the warehouse for flexibility.

@tayloramurphy @edgarrmondragon @aaronsteers what are youre thoughts on this? We can start brainstorming a structure so its easier to implement once https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3019 is ready.


**UPDATE (4-19-22)**

Next steps are the come up with the event structure of our v2 custom attributes that we will send to Snowplow.

Steps:
- [x] select top events to model (~5)
- [x] define the ideal attributes to send
- [ ] of the ideal list determine what is feasible and will be implemented (if not all)
- [ ] agree on the structure of the payload thats easy to build and send on the Meltano side and is also easy to parse and use on the warehouse side
- [ ] define json schemas as needed

epic.title: Enhance Telemetry across Meltano, SDK, and Hub

_decoded_content.title: Telemetry User ID
_decoded_content.description:
It looks like Google Analytics calculates active user metrics using a [Client ID](https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/collection/protocol/v1/reference
) 

>  Client ID | cid | cid=xxxxx | An ID unique to a particular user. |

that we send with the [event payload](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/master/src/meltano/core/tracking/ga_tracker.py#L98).

The problem with our implementation of this is that it looks like we use a `.meltano/analytics.json` [file](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/master/src/meltano/core/tracking/ga_tracker.py#L44) to store the client ID which is created on the first run then retrieved and sent on each run after that but its not checked into version control. Its really common for users to have an ephemeral runtime environment (i.e. Squared and MeltanoHub) with a fresh `meltano install` each time its run. In this case they look like a new user on each instantiation.

I know that we're in the process of moving off of google analytics but it seems like we should be using the project_id from the `meltano.yml` file as our unique identifier.

_decoded_content.title: Add additional Snowplow events
_decoded_content.description:
From https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2972, there are more events we'd like to track:

* EL job start/stop timestamps
* T job start/stop timestamps
* Exit codes
* Meltano version
* Caller script (Airflow, Dagster, direct, etc.)
* Environment
* Installed features - orchestrators (Airflow, Dagster), dbt, Utilities (Lightdash/Superset), Files (Docker)
* Plugin variant, name, pip_url, version

These won't all be done in this issue, but can be broken out from here.

We want basically all of the requirements from https://gitlab.com/meltano/sdk/-/issues/141#note_602040376 :

* Default to Meltano collector, but completely configurable for the end user
* Update documentation to indicate it's obvious where the data goes and what we're doing with it (back to the Hub)

@aaronsteers any concerns around this?

_decoded_content.title: Add Snowplow Tracking to Meltano
_decoded_content.description:
https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/master/src/meltano/core/tracking/ga_tracker.py seems to be the primary place where GA Events are defined. All instances of `GoogleAnalyticsTracker` would have to be updated as well.

The aim of this issue would be to have 100% parity for Snowplow events with what we had for GA.

2022-02-24 Update

After syncing with Snowcat Cloud and the team we're aiming to do the following:

* Get the end-to-end data flowing to both GA and Snowplow
* This means using the structured event format to achieve parity with what we have in GA
  * This is a known sub-optimal approach as we aim to overhaul all events with proper schemas and structure
* New events should only be added following improved schema workflow and control

## Implementation Outline

<details><summary>(larger scope)</summary>

- [ ] create a new `MeltanoTracking` class to track usage, with support for many `BaseTracker` instances
- [ ] create a new `BaseTracker` class to host generic tracking methods
- [ ] create new `SnowplowTracker` class, inheriting from `BaseTracker`, to forward to Snowplow
- [ ] adapt `GoogleAnalyticsTracker` to inherit from `BaseTracker`
- [ ] replace all uses of `GoogleAnalyticsTracker` with `MeltanoTracking`

</details>

epic.title: Enhance Telemetry across Meltano, SDK, and Hub

_decoded_content.title: Stand-up full Snowplow Infrastructure
_decoded_content.description:
Based on https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2972, we have decided to use and implement Snowplow for the open source event tracking. 

Given that the team has experience with AWS and Snowplow, deploying the infrastructure on our own AWS infra is ideal sicne it gives us full control of the data.

This issue tracks the work to get everything stood up on the AWS side. At the end of it, we should have a URL we can send events to which will be enriched and landed in S3. [This project](https://gitlab.com/meltano/saved-from-gitlab/gitlab-com-infrastructure/-/tree/master/environments/aws-snowplow) can serve as a detailed guide on how to get it working.

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gitlab-com-infrastructure/-/tree/master/environments/aws-snowplow is also available!

epic.title: Enhance Telemetry across Meltano, SDK, and Hub
